SUBPROGRAM AND LOAN SUMMARY 
   
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
Classification  Targeted classification: General intervention  
Sector  (subsector):  Public  sector  management  (economic 
management  and management of public affairs) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Economic  growth  (promoting 
macroeconomic  stability,  promoting  economic  efficiency  and 
enabling  business  environment),  social  development  (human 
development), environmental sustainability (environmental policy and 
legislation), governance (economic and financial governance, public 
administration [national and decentralized], anticorruption) 
Climate change: Mitigation and adaptation 
Location Impact: National (high impact), rural (low impact)  
Partnerships:  Agencia  Española  de  Cooperación  Internacional, 
Australian  Agency  for  International  Development,  Canadian 
International  Development  Agency,  Danish  International 
Development  Agency,  European  Commission,  Government  of 
Germany, Government of New Zealand, Government of Switzerland, 
Irish  Aid,  Japan  International  Corporation  Agency,  Netherlands 
Directorate General for International Cooperation, United Kingdom’s 
Department for International Development, World Bank   
   
Environmental  Subprogram 2 of the Support for the Implementation of the Poverty 
Assessment  Reduction Program (SIPRP) V has been assigned to environmental 
category C. A review of its environmental implications indicates that 
several policy actions covered by the subprogram are likely to have a 
positive environmental impact. Enhancement measures have been 
developed to optimize these positive impacts. No action has been 
identified as likely to have an adverse environmental impact. 
   
Subprogram  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved SIPRP V, a program 
Description  cluster  consisting  of  three  subprograms,  and  a  loan  for  its 
subprogram 1 in December 2008. SIPRP V is intended to help the 
Government of Viet Nam carry out policy reforms that are needed for 
the successful implementation of its Socioeconomic Development 
Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010. To this end, SIPRP V is to provide parallel 
financing with the World Bank’s poverty reduction support credits 
(PRSCs)  7–9  within  the  framework  of  the  PRSC  process. 
Subprogram 1 provided parallel financing with PRSC 7. 
 
Subprogram 2 will provide parallel financing with PRSC 8, covering a 
subset of actions included in the policy matrix for PRSC 8. Like the 
policy  actions  covered  by  subprogram  1,  the  actions  under 
subprogram  2  fall  into  the  four  broad  reform  areas:  business 
development, social inclusion, natural resource management, and 
governance. They complement actions supported by ADB's other 
program  loans to  Viet Nam  or  are  otherwise  important to  ADB's 
operations in the country. Most of them were on the combined list of 
tentative actions under subprograms 2 and 3 in the original policy

ii   
matrix of SIPRP V. ADB staff took part in the consultations on these 
actions,  which  the  Government  and  the  development  agencies 
participating in the PRSC process held between December 2008 and 
May 2009. All of the actions have been completed, although two of 
them have not been carried out exactly as envisaged. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact and the outcome of the proposed subprogram are the 
same as those of SIPRP V. The intended impact of SIPRP V is a 
continued  reduction  in  poverty  in  Viet  Nam  in  2008–2010  and 
beyond. Its expected outcome is the successful implementation of 
the  Government’s  SEDP  2006–2010,  which  will  not  only  reduce 
poverty  in  2006–2010  but  also  improve  Viet  Nam’s  economic 
competitiveness and strengthen the foundations for inclusive and 
sustainable  growth  and  a  continued  reduction  in  poverty  beyond 
2010. 
   
Cost Estimates  Some of the policy actions covered by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V 
entail substantial costs to Viet Nam’s state budget. The total cost to 
the state budget in 2009–2011 of the actions included in the policy 
matrix for PRSC 8 is estimated at $680 million.  
   
Financing Plan  The  World  Bank  has  already  approved  PRSC  8  amounting  to 
$350 million from the International Development Association. Other 
development agencies participating in the PRSC process (including 
ADB) are expected to provide grants or concessional loans totaling 
about $250 million in cofinancing or parallel financing with PRSC 8. 
The remaining costs to the budget of the actions included in the 
policy matrix for PRSC 8 will be covered by the Government. 
   
Loan Amount and  It  is  proposed  that  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
Terms  SDR64,036,000 be provided for subprogram 2 from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources. The loan will have a term of 24 years, including a 
grace period of 8 years; an annual interest rate of 1.0% during the 
grace period and 1.5% during the amortization period; and other 
terms and conditions set forth in the Loan Agreement. The loan 
proceeds may be used to finance eligible imports incurred within 
180 days before the date of loan effectiveness.  
   
Executing Agency  The State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) is the Executing Agency for 
SIPRP V. As such, it will be the Executing Agency for the proposed 
subprogram. 
   
Disbursement  The proposed loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon the 
declaration of loan effectiveness.  
 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed to the Socialist Republic of 
Viet Nam  as  the  Borrower  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998).

iii 
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and 
procured in ADB member countries, excluding ineligible items and 
imports financed from other bilateral and multilateral sources. No 
supporting import documentation will be required provided that the 
value of Viet Nam’s total imports minus imports from nonmember 
countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official 
development assistance is at least equal to the amount of the loan to 
be disbursed. The Government will certify its compliance with this 
formula with its withdrawal request. Otherwise, import documentation 
under existing procedures will be required. ADB will have the right to 
audit the use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the 
Borrower’s certification. 
 
Period of Utilization  The loan will be fully utilized by 31 May 2010. 
   
Subprogram Benefits  The policy reforms that SIPRP V and, in particular, its subprogram 2 
and Beneficiaries  are intended to advance will yield considerable economic benefits to 
Viet Nam and substantial financial benefits to the Government. They 
will raise the living standards of the Vietnamese people by fostering 
socially inclusive and environmentally sustainable economic growth. 
The reforms will also increase budget revenue by expanding the tax 
base, and reduce budget expenditure by improving public financial 
management. Over the medium term, the financial benefits of these 
reforms to the Government are likely to exceed their costs (including 
interest  to  be  paid  on  loans  received  from  various  development 
agencies within the framework of the PRSC process). 
   
Assumptions and  SIPRP V and, in particular, its subprogram 2 are to support policy 
Risks  actions that are critical steps in the policy reforms needed for the 
successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010 and are important to 
ADB’s operations in Viet Nam. However, the reforms need to be fully 
carried out if SEDP 2006–2010 is to be successfully implemented. 
Therefore, it is assumed that, after completing the policy actions 
covered by SIPRP V and the other actions included in the policy 
matrices  for  the  World  Bank’s  PRSCs  7–9,  the  Government  will 
follow  through  with  the  policy  reforms  needed for  the  successful 
implementation of SEDP 2006–2010 on its own or with the support of 
development agencies under other projects. It is further assumed 
that the investment projects that are included in SEDP 2006–2010 
and necessary for attaining its targets and goals will be implemented 
on schedule.  
 
These assumptions are based on the Government’s commitment to 
carry out the policy reforms and implement the investment projects 
that are needed to achieve the targets and goals of SEDP 2006–
2010. Furthermore, policy reforms that are needed for the successful 
implementation of SEDP 2006–2010 are now or will be supported by 
ADB through other policy-based loans to Viet Nam, and by other 
development  agencies  within  and  outside  the  framework  of  the 
PRSC process.

iv   
The slowdown of growth caused by the global economic crisis could 
be so prolonged that it will preclude the successful implementation of 
SEDP 2006–2010 and, in particular, the achievement of its target 
related to the poverty rate. However, this risk is small. The fiscal 
stimulus  measures  adopted  by  the  Government  in  January–May 
2009 are expected to spur growth in the second half of 2009 and in 
2010. Moreover, the external environment is expected to improve 
significantly in 2010. Accordingly, growth is likely to rebound in the 
second half of 2009 and accelerate further in 2010. 
 
As economic growth accelerates and world commodity prices rise, 
inflation  could  surge  again.  High  inflation  could  push  many 
households into poverty and preclude the successful implementation 
of  SEDP  2006–2010.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  the  SBV  has  started 
taking  measures  to  keep  inflation  in  check.  In  particular,  it  has 
committed to limit growth of money supply to 30% in 2009; asked 
state-owned commercial banks to limit loan growth to 25% in 2009; 
and  urged  all  commercial  banks  to  tighten  credit  for  consumer 
spending  and  purchases  of  real  estate  and  stocks.  The  SBV  is 
expected to start tightening monetary policy toward the end of 2009 
and pursue moderately tight monetary policy in 2010.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for subprogram 2 of the Support for the Implementation of 
the Poverty Reduction Program (SIPRP) V. The updated design and monitoring framework for 
SIPRP V is in Appendix 1. 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Viet Nam's economy expanded rapidly in the past 2 decades. Real gross domestic 
product (GDP) grew at the average annual rate of 7.4% in 1988–2007. Following a modest 
slowdown in 1998–1999 caused by the Asian financial crisis, growth of real GDP accelerated 
almost steadily during 2000–2007, from 4.8% in 1999 to 8.5% in 2007.  
 
3.  However, the country has been experiencing severe macroeconomic difficulties since 
2008.  Inflation  and  the  trade  deficit  surged  in  the  first  half  of  2008.  The  macroeconomic 
imbalances, which built up for several years and manifested themselves in inflation pressures 
and persistent trade deficits, were exacerbated by domestic supply-side shocks (such as poultry 
epidemics).  The  rise  in  world  commodity  prices  contributed  to  the  surge  in  inflation.  The 
Government responded by tightening monetary and fiscal policies and adopting other measures 
to stabilize the macroeconomic situation.  
 
4.  In the second half of 2008, inflation fell sharply and the trade deficit narrowed, in part 
because of the stabilization measures of the Government in the first half of the year. The drop in 
world commodity prices helped bring inflation down. At the same time, economic activity slowed 
markedly, as external demand weakened substantially. In response, the Government started 
loosening monetary and fiscal policies. Still, growth of real GDP decelerated to 6.2% in 2008 
from more than 8.0% in the preceding 3 years (Table 1). 
 
5.  In  2008,  the  global  economic  crisis  slowed  the  growth  of  Viet  Nam's  exports  and 
contributed to the decrease in portfolio investment inflows. It has had additional adverse impacts 
on Viet Nam in 2009. In particular, the crisis has further crimped exports. It has also reduced 
revenue  from  international  tourism  and  inflows  of  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI).  Exports 
decreased by 10.2%, the number of international tourist arrivals fell by 22.1%, and gross FDI 
inflows declined by 22.5% in January–June 2009 compared with the same period a year earlier. 
Accordingly, year-on-year growth of real GDP slowed to 3.9% in the first half of 2009, from 6.5% 
in the first half of 2008. With GDP most likely falling below its potential level, year-on-year 
inflation eased to 2.0% in August 2009 from 28.3% in August 2008. 
 
6.  The Government has adopted a range of measures to mitigate the adverse impact of the 
global economic crisis on growth and poverty in Viet Nam. These measures include one-off 
additional financial assistance to poor households, housing support for the poor, and provision 
of interest-free short-term loans to firms that have had to shed at least 30% of their staff and are 
experiencing difficulties in paying wages of the remaining staff. Furthermore, the Government 
has increased the budgetary allocation for the existing social assistance programs, such as the 
program for poverty reduction in ethnic minority and mountainous areas (so-called Program 135) 
and  the  health  insurance  program  for  the  poor  and  near-poor.  It  has  also  expedited  the 
formulation and approval of the program for accelerated poverty reduction in the 61 poorest 
districts. In the central Government budget for 2009, $935 million has been allocated to social 
safety nets, compared with $518 million spent on social safety nets from this budget in 2008.

2

3 
III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance  
1.  Recent Progress in Poverty Reduction 
7.  Viet Nam reduced poverty dramatically in the past 15–20 years (Appendix 2). According 
to the most recent available household survey data, the poverty rate (based on the cost of a 
consumption basket allowing for a daily intake of 2,100 calories per person and some nonfood 
expenditure) dropped from 58.1% in 1993 to 16.0% in 2006.1 The food poverty rate fell from 
24.9% to 6.7% over the same period, while the poverty gap narrowed from 18.5% to 3.8%.2  
 
8.  Measures of poverty not based on household survey data point to declines of similar 
magnitudes in poverty, although they give different levels of poverty. In particular, the proportion 
of people living on less than $1.0 per day based on purchasing power parity (PPP) dropped 
from 50.8% of the population in 1990 to 4.0% in 2007, and the proportion living on less than 
$2.0  per  day  based  on  PPP  fell  from  87.0%  to  32.9%.3 The  poverty  rate  based  on  the 
methodology of the Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA) fell from 20.2% in 
2005 to an estimated 13.1% in 2008.4  
 
9.  A combination of strong economic growth and more efficient social protection enabled 
Viet Nam to make such great strides in poverty reduction.5 Economic growth created new jobs, 
raised incomes, and lifted millions of people out of poverty. However, growth alone would not 
have enabled Viet Nam to reduce poverty as much as it has done. Many of those who did not 
benefit directly from economic growth (often for reasons beyond their control) were lifted out of 
poverty or prevented from falling into poverty because more resources became available for 
social  protection  (thanks  to  the  strong  economic  growth)  and  social  protection  became 
significantly more efficient.  
2.  Poverty Reduction Support Credit Process 
10.  The main reason why Viet Nam was able to sustain rapid economic growth for a long 
time and to improve the efficiency of social protection significantly is that, since 1986, the 
country has carried out a broad range of policy reforms fostering sustainable and inclusive 
economic growth and making social protection more targeted. In particular, Viet Nam has been 
undertaking a gradual transition from a command to a market economy, and from a social 
protection  system  that  relies  heavily  on  price  subsidies  to  a  system  based  on  targeted 
programs. It has also continually strengthened natural resource management and improved 
governance. Since 2002, more and more multilateral and bilateral development agencies have 
supported these reforms through the poverty reduction support credit (PRSC) process led by 
the World Bank.  
                                                
1  World Bank. 2007. Vietnam Development Report 2008: Social Protection. Joint donor report to the Vietnam 
Consultative Group Meeting, Hanoi, 6–7 December 2007. 
2  The food poverty rate is the proportion of people whose total expenditure would not be enough for a daily intake of 
2,100 calories even if it were entirely allocated to food. The poverty gap is the difference between the poverty line 
and the average expenditure of the poor expressed as a percentage of the former. 
3   World Bank. 2008. East Asia: Testing Times Ahead. Washington, DC. 
4  The poverty rate based on the methodology of MOLISA measures the proportion of people living below the official 
poverty line, which is D260,000 per person in urban areas and D200,000 per person in rural areas. Households 
below  the  poverty line  are identified  by local  officials  of  MOLISA  through  a  combination  of  their  personal 
knowledge, survey techniques, and village discussions.  
5   Although economic growth slowed in 2008, it was still faster than that in many other countries around the world.

4 
 
11.  The PRSC process comprises several closely related activities jointly undertaken each 
year by participating development agencies to help the Government carry out the policy reforms 
needed  for  the  successful  implementation  of  its  poverty  reduction  strategy.  The  process 
involves  the  preparation  of  Viet  Nam  development  reports  by  participating  agencies, 
consultations on the policy matrices for the World Bank’s PRSCs among participating agencies 
and between these agencies and the Government, and general budget support (in the form of 
grants and concessional loans) to Viet Nam by participating agencies to cover some of the 
adjustment costs of the policy reforms to the budget. The World Bank coordinates PRSC 
activities for the participating development agencies. 
  
12.  While the Government’s poverty reduction strategy largely determines its reform agenda, 
the  Viet  Nam  development  reports  translate  this  agenda  into  policy  actions.  Because  a 
sustained reduction in poverty requires continued and balanced progress on a wide range of 
policy reforms, the Government has an extensive reform agenda and the Viet Nam development 
reports specify numerous policy actions in many different areas.  
 
13.  Some of these actions are included in the policy matrices for PRSCs. During the year 
before the World Bank is expected to approve a particular PRSC, the participating development 
agencies agree among themselves and with the Government on the initial policy matrix for the 
PRSC. At the start of the year in which the World Bank is to approve the PRSC, the agencies 
hold joint consultations with the Government on individual policy actions included in the initial 
matrix. When the World Bank undertakes the appraisal and the negotiations for the PRSC 
(usually in May of the year when the PRSC is expected to be approved), the agencies and the 
Government agree on the final policy matrix for that PRSC. Some actions that were included in 
the  initial  policy  matrix  are  modified  or  dropped  at  this  stage,  based  on  their  status  and 
likelihood of being completed before the World Bank’s executive board deliberates on the PRSC.  
 
14.  Actions in all key reform areas are usually included in the policy matrices for PRSCs to 
help the Government make balanced progress in reforms across various areas and fully carry 
out its reform agenda. Therefore, the policy matrices for PRSCs tend to be broad in scope and 
to closely match the Government’s reform agenda. This makes the PRSC process attractive to 
many development agencies (focusing on different areas of policy reforms) and contributes to 
the strong government ownership of the actions included in the policy matrices for PRSCs.  
 
15.  At the same time, the good-practice principle of criticality in development policy lending 
guides the selection of policy actions within a particular reform area. According to this principle, 
only those actions that are critical to the achievement of results should be made conditions for 
disbursement.6 Therefore, the policy matrices for PRSCs include only those actions that the 
participating development agencies and the Government consider to be critical steps in the 
reform process in the area concerned, and for which the Government needs the combined 
support  of  many  development  agencies.  The  Government  follows  through  with  the  reform 
process on its own or with the support of development agencies under other projects. This 
approach helps keep the policy matrices for PRSCs manageable despite their broad scope. 
However, it also limits the continuity of actions included in the policy matrices for various PRSCs. 
 
16.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) joined the PRSC process in 2003 and has taken 
part in most PRSC activities since then. In 2004, ADB approved SIPRP I, a single-tranche 
standard program loan of $6.4 million. SIPRP I provided parallel financing with the World Bank’s 
                                                
6  World Bank. 2005. Review of World Bank Conditionality. http://go.worldbank.org/RY7IJPEPZ0

5 
PRSC  3  in  support  of  the  implementation  of  the  Government’s  Comprehensive  Poverty 
Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS) 2002–2006. SIPRP II ($15 million) was approved in 
2005 and provided parallel financing with PRSC 4. SIPRP III ($15 million) was approved in 2006 
and provided parallel financing with PRSC 5. Like SIPRP I, SIPRP II and SIPRP III were single-
tranche standard program loans, which supported the implementation of CPRGS 2002–2006.7 
With support from ADB, the World Bank, and other development agencies through the PRSC 
process, the policy reforms needed for the successful implementation of CPRGS 2002–2006 
were carried out and most of the CPRGS goals were achieved.8 
3.  Socioeconomic Development Plan 2006–2010 
17.  The Government adopted the Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010 in 
2006. Unlike previous SEDPs, SEDP 2006–2010 was prepared in an open and participatory 
manner  involving  extensive  consultations  with  civil  society,  businesses,  and  development 
agencies.  It  is  oriented  more  toward  attaining  development  outcomes  (including  poverty 
reduction) and less toward achieving production targets. One of its main targets is to reduce the 
poverty rate (based on MOLISA’s methodology) from 20.2% in 2005 to 10%–11% in 2010. 
SEDP 2006–2010 also aspires to strengthen the foundations for environmentally sustainable 
and socially inclusive economic growth, and a continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. It 
provides for a broad range of policy reforms and a large number of investment projects aimed at 
achieving its targets and goals. The joint International Development Association–International 
Monetary  Fund  staff  advisory  note  of  5 December 2006  on  Viet  Nam’s  poverty  reduction 
strategy concluded that SEDP 2006–2010 has the key features of a poverty reduction strategy 
and is likely to lead to economic growth and poverty reduction.9 
 
18.  Since late 2006, the PRSC process has supported the policy reforms needed for the 
successful  implementation  of  SEDP  2006–2010.  In  2007,  about  a  dozen  multilateral  and 
bilateral development agencies, including ADB, provided general budget support to Viet Nam 
within the framework of the PRSC process to help the Government keep these reforms on track 
in  2007.  ADB  approved  SIPRP  IV  (another  single-tranche  standard  program  loan  for  $15 
million) for this purpose in October 2007.

B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Challenges in Poverty Reduction 
19.  Despite the tremendous strides Viet Nam has made in reducing poverty over the past 
15–20 years, much remains to be done. First, the absolute number of poor people is still large, 
although their share in the total population has dropped drastically. According to the household 
survey data, 13.5 million people lived in poverty and 5.7 million people suffered from hunger in 
2006. The poverty rate based on MOLISA's methodology suggests that 11.3 million people lived 
below the official poverty line in 2008. 
 
20.  Second, the incidence of poverty is still high in rural areas and among ethnic minorities, 
although it has been decreasing faster than in urban areas and among the ethnic majority. In 
2006, the poverty rate was 20.4% in rural areas (compared with 3.9% in urban areas) and 
52.2% among ethnic minorities (compared with 10.2% among the Kinh and Chinese majority) 
(footnote 1). Rural areas accounted for 73.3% of the total population but 93.6% of the poor. 
Ethnic minorities made up 13.5% of the total population but 44.4% of the poor.10 
 
21.  Third, the rural poor and poor ethnic minority people not only account for relatively large 
proportions of their respective population groups, but also have significantly lower average 
incomes than the urban poor and poor ethnic majority people, respectively. In 2006, the poverty 
gap was 4.9% in the rural areas and 15.4% among ethnic minorities, compared with 3.2% in the 
urban areas and 2.0% among the Kinh and Chinese majority (footnote 1). 
 
22.  Fourth,  the  incidence  of poverty  varies significantly  across regions. It  is  low  in  the 
Southeast, Red River Delta, Mekong Delta, and South Central Coast, but high in the Northern 
Mountains (especially the Northwest Mountains), North Central Coast, and Central Highlands. In 
2006,  the  poverty  rate  was  30.2%  in  the  Northern  Mountains  (49.0%  in  the  Northwest 
Mountains), 29.1% in the North Central Coast, and 28.6% in the Central Highlands, compared 
with 5.8% in the Southeast and 8.8% in the Red River Delta (footnote 1). 
 
23.  Fifth, the vulnerability of the population to poverty is rather high. The large difference 
between the proportion of the population living on less than $2.0 per day based on PPP (32.9% 
in 2007) and the share of those living on less than $1.0 per day based on PPP (4.0% in 2007) 
suggests that the near-poor account for a substantial proportion of the population. A small 
external or internal shock and a moderate deterioration in the economic situation can push 
many of these people into poverty. 
 
24.  Finally, some negative trends in poverty have emerged recently. The household survey 
data show that urban poverty increased between 2004 and 2006. The poverty rate rose from 
3.6% in 2004 to 3.9% in 2006, while the food poverty rate increased from 0.8% to 1.2% 
(footnote 1). Anecdotal evidence suggests that high inflation and, in particular, the steep rise of 
food prices pushed many low-income households, especially in urban areas, into poverty in 
2008. As economic activity slowed sharply, unemployment and underemployment increased 
and more households, particularly in rural areas, fell into poverty in the first several months of 
2009. Many people from rural areas who were employed in urban areas of Viet Nam or abroad 
                                                
10 World Bank. 2008. Taking Stock: An Update on Vietnam’s Recent Economic Developments. Paper prepared for 
the Mid-Year Consultative Group Meeting for Vietnam, Sapa, 5–6 June 2008.

7 
lost their jobs and stopped sending remittances to their households. Some of them returned to 
their villages, even though they have few alternative sources of income there.11 
2.  Opportunities Afforded by the Poverty Reduction Support Credit Process 
25.  To meet the remaining challenges of poverty reduction, Viet Nam needs, among other 
things, to press ahead with the policy reforms that increase the efficiency of social protection, 
and foster environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive economic growth. These reforms 
will help Viet Nam limit the adverse impact of the global economic crisis on growth, employment, 
and poverty and quickly resume rapid economic growth and poverty reduction.  
 
26.  However, some of these reforms, such as restructuring state-owned enterprises (SOEs) 
and reforming the health care and education systems, are complex. Moreover, their costs to the 
economy as a whole and to the state budget in particular are likely to exceed their benefits in 
the short term. Therefore, they are likely to put a considerable burden on the state budget in the 
short  term  and  result  in  net  losses  for  some  economic  actors  even  over  the  long  term. 
Consequently, potential losers are likely to resist some of these reforms.  
 
27.  Strong support from development partners, through the PRSC process, can help the 
Government  carry  out  these  reforms.  In  2006,  under  the  auspices  of  the  Network  on 
Development Evaluation of the Development Assistance Committee of the Organization for 
Economic Co-operation and Development, several development agencies and governments 
commissioned an evaluation study of partnership general budget support (PGBS) operations in 
seven developing countries, including Viet Nam. The study looked into the relevance, efficiency, 
and effectiveness of PGBS (involving several development agencies and the government). It 
found that the PRSC process in Viet Nam is an efficient, effective, and sustainable way of 
supporting national poverty reduction strategies. PGBS can significantly affect policies and 
policy processes through financial empowerment, stronger incentives within government, and 
better coherence and coordination among international partners. In the countries covered by the 
study, PGBS has reinforced collaboration between governments and development agencies, 
and has improved harmonization of official development assistance. It has helped make public 
finance  management  more  comprehensive  and  transparent,  increased  pro-poor  public 
expenditures, and resulted in large savings to the government in transaction costs. The PRSC 
process in Viet Nam has had a strong positive impact on policy reforms. It is an example of 
successful  government–donor  collaboration,  of  learning  from  experience,  and  of  objectives 
met.12  
 
28.  Indeed, the PRSC process has been a driving force of policy reforms in Viet Nam in 
recent years. The Government has used the involvement of a large number of development 
agencies (including ADB) in the process to overcome domestic resistance to policy reforms. To

half of 2009 is not available yet. The most recent Viet Nam Household Living Standards Survey was conducted in 
2008, and the data it has generated are being processed. 
12 The study also points out several shortcomings of the PRSC process in Viet Nam (some of which were fully or

large number of the participating development agencies, which makes the coordination of the process more difficult 
and hinders its cohesion (International Development Department and Associates. 2006. Evaluation of General 
Budget Support: Synthesis Report. Birmingham: University of Birmingham.  
http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/25/43/37426676.pdf)

8 
deal  with  such  resistance,  government  agencies  advocating  certain  reforms  have  often 
proposed the inclusion of these measures in the policy matrices for the PRSCs.  
 
29.  According to the World Bank’s report on the implementation and results of PRSCs 1–5, 
the first phase of the PRSC process in Viet Nam (which supported the implementation of 
CPRGS 2002–2006) contributed to the significant achievements by the country in its transition 
to a market economy, social inclusion, and the building of modern governance. The PRSC 
process had a direct influence on the adoption of policy actions that were conducive to faster 
economic growth and poverty reduction, and helped spread market mechanisms, create wage 
employment, and improve the delivery of public services. The annual PRSC cycle with tight 
deadlines increased incentives to complete key policy actions on time. In addition, the PRSC 
process helped the Government strengthen its capacity to conduct cross-sector policy dialogue 
and deliver results on time. Consultations with a large number of development agencies within 
the framework of the PRSC process showed the Government the benefits of an open dialogue 
on key issues, and made it more receptive to sharing its draft documents at an early stage and 
eliciting feedback from the stakeholders.13 
 
30.  Stakeholder consultations that were held in 2006 as part of an independent evaluation of 
the first phase of the PRSC process found that the process was beneficial to policy reforms in 
Viet Nam. Both the Government and the participating development agencies emphasized that 
the policy dialogue within the framework of the PRSC process was a major benefit of the 
process. The Government valued the ideas offered by the development agencies on the design 
and  implementation  of  policy  reforms,  while  the  development  agencies  gained  a  broader 
understanding of the direction of the reform process and government thinking. Other PRSC 
benefits stemmed not only from improving the quality of policies, but also from locking in the 
Government’s commitment to specific reforms and speeding up their implementation.14 
IV.  SUPPORT FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE POVERTY REDUCTION 
PROGRAM V 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
31.  ADB approved SIPRP V, a program cluster consisting of three subprograms, and a 
single-tranche loan (about $25 million) for its subprogram 1 in December 2008.15 The intended 
impact of SIPRP V is a continued reduction in poverty in Viet Nam in 2008–2010 and beyond. 
Its expected outcome is the successful implementation of the Government’s SEDP 2006–2010, 
which  will  not  only reduce  poverty  in  2006–2010,  but  also  enhance  Viet  Nam's  economic 
competitiveness and strengthen the foundations for inclusive and sustainable growth and a 
continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. To achieve this outcome, SIPRP V is to help the 
Government carry out policy reforms that are needed for the successful implementation of 
SEDP 2006–2010. Specifically, SIPRP V is to support—through the PRSC process—policy 
actions that are critical steps in carrying out the reforms and are important to ADB’s operations 
in Viet Nam. 
                                                
13 World Bank. 2007. Implementation Completion and Results Report on a Series of Five Credits in the Total Amount 
of SDR473.4 Million (US$650 Million Equivalent) to the Socialist Republic of Vietnam for a Series of Five Poverty 
Reduction Support Operations. Washington, DC (Report No. ICR0000483).  
14 Bartholomew, Ann, and Catherine Dom. 2006. Using Aid Well: Experience and Opportunities with Vietnam’s 
PRSC. Oxford, United Kingdom: Mokoro Ltd. 
15 ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on the Proposed Program 
Cluster and Loan for Subprogram 1 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Support for the Implementation of 
the Poverty Reduction Program V. Manila.

9 
 
32.  The policy actions supported by SIPRP V fall into the following four broad reform areas: 
 
(i)  Business  development.  Improving  financial  management  and  corporate 
governance of SOEs, developing the financial and private sectors, and improving 
the quality of infrastructure services. 
(ii)  Social inclusion. Improving the quality of health care and education, and access 
to these services.  
(iii)  Natural  resource  management.  Strengthening  the  management  of  water 
resources and the protection of the environment.  
(iv)  Governance.  Improving  planning  processes,  strengthening  public  financial 
management and pubic administration, and reducing corruption.16  
 
33.  These  reforms closely  match  the  priorities  of ADB's  country  strategy  and  program, 
2007–2010  for  Viet  Nam.  The  primary  focus  of  the  country  strategy  and  program  is  on 
promoting business-led, pro-poor economic growth by developing infrastructure, improving the 
business environment, strengthening financial and related market institutions, and building up 
human capital. The country strategy and program also aims to foster social inclusiveness, 
enhance management of the environment, and improve governance.17  
B.  Important Features 
34.  SIPRP V follows the program-based approach and is, in some respects, a continuation 
of SIPRPs I–IV. It is to provide parallel financing with the World Bank’s PRSCs within the 
framework of the PRSC process. Like SIPRP IV, it is intended to help the Government carry out 
policy reforms needed for the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010.  
 
35.  Unlike SIPRPs I–IV, SIPRP V takes the program cluster approach. It consists of three 
chronologically ordered subprograms. Subprogram 1 provided parallel financing with PRSC 7, 
subprogram 2 is to provide parallel financing with PRSC 8, and subprogram 3 is to provide 
parallel financing with PRSC 9. The outputs, outcome, impact, and performance indicators and 
targets of SIPRP V are the same for all its subprograms. 
 
36.  Individual  subprograms  of  SIPRP  V  can  only  cover  actions  included  in  the  policy 
matrices of the corresponding PRSCs. Moreover, they are to focus on those actions in the 
policy matrices for PRSCs 7–9 that complement actions supported by ADB’s other program 
loans to Viet Nam or are otherwise important to ADB’s operations in the country.  
 
37.  Nevertheless, SIPRP V has a broad scope because the policy matrices for PRSCs 
include actions in many reform areas. Further, ADB is active in many sectors in Viet Nam, and 
policy reforms in these sectors often have significant implications for its operations. At the same 
time,  only  limited  continuity  can  be  expected  in  the  policy  actions  supported  by  various 
subprograms of SIPRP V because of the limited continuity in the policy matrices for different 
PRSCs.  
 
38.  SIPRP V is a general intervention aiming to help Viet Nam reduce poverty, but its impact 
on poverty will largely be indirect. The policy reforms supported by SIPRP V will improve 
                                                
16 Figure A3.1 in Appendix 3 shows graphically how the policy reforms supported by SIPRP V will contribute to its 
outcome. 
17 ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program (2007–2010): Viet Nam. Manila.

10 
governance, develop businesses, and stimulate economic growth. Business development and 
economic growth will create news jobs, raise incomes, and make more resources available for 
social protection. Poor and vulnerable people in both rural and urban areas, ethnic minorities, 
and poor regions will benefit from more jobs, higher incomes, and increased availability of 
resources for social protection. The reforms supported by SIPRP V will also make economic 
growth more socially inclusive and environmentally sustainable by improving the quality of 
health care and education and access to these services, and by strengthening the management 
of  natural  resources.  Hence,  SIPRP  V  complements  ADB's  targeted  poverty-reducing 
interventions in Viet Nam, which seek to reduce poverty in a particular region within the country 
or among ethnic minorities.  
C.  Subprogram 1 and Lessons 
39.  Subprogram 1 of SIPRP V covered 12 of 35 actions included in the policy matrix for 
PRSC 7. All of these actions were completed before ADB approved the loan for the subprogram. 
Therefore, loan effectiveness was the only condition for loan disbursement. The loan became 
effective in April 2009 and was disbursed in May 2009. 
 
40.  Two notable lessons emerged from the formulation and implementation of subprogram 
1.  First, the  policy  reform  process slows  when  Viet  Nam faces macroeconomic  difficulties 
because the Government focuses its efforts on overcoming these difficulties and cannot devote 
enough staff resources to reforms. The reform process slowed in the first half of 2008, when 
inflation and the trade deficit surged, and the Government's top policy priority became stabilizing 
the macroeconomic situation. Second, a fall in stock prices causes delays in equitization of 
SOEs  and  state-owned  commercial  banks  (SOCBs). While  recognizing  that  equitization  of 
SOEs is essential to improving their corporate governance and efficiency, the Government does 
not  want  to  sell  their  shares  when  stock  prices  are  low.  These  lessons  were  taken  into 
consideration when the proposed subprogram was formulated (paras. 52 and 54). 
D.  Progress towards Performance Targets 
41.  Despite the macroeconomic turbulence and the slowdown in economic growth, Viet Nam 
made good overall progress towards the performance targets of SIPRP V in 2008. Due mainly 
to the Government's targeted interventions, the poverty rate based on MOLISA's methodology 
fell from 14.7% in 2007 to an estimated 13.1% in 2008 (Appendix 4). Hence, Viet Nam is on 
track to reduce the poverty rate to 10%–11% by 2010, which is one of the main targets of SEDP 
2006–2010 and one of the two outcome targets of SIPRP V.  
 
42.  At the  same  time,  the progress  towards  the  other  outcome  target  of SIPRP  V—to 
increase Viet Nam's Global Competitiveness Index score from 4.04 in 2007–2008 to 4.60 in 
2010–2011—was relatively slow. The score increased to 4.10 in 2008–2009. Increases in the 
subscores for goods market efficiency, financial markets sophistication, infrastructure, health, 
education, institutions, and innovation were partly offset by a sharp decrease in the subscore for 
macroeconomic stability.  
 
43.  As for the SIPRP V output targets pertaining to business development, Viet Nam has 
achieved the target related to the share of FDI in total investment, and is on track to attain the 
target concerning the share of nonperforming loans (NPLs) in the loan portfolio of commercial 
banks (often referred to as the NPL ratio). Despite tight global financial conditions, FDI inflows 
to Viet Nam surged in 2008. As a result, the share of FDI in total investment jumped from 16.0%

11 
in 2007 to 29.8% in 2008, compared with the SIPRP V target of 20% in 2010. FDI inflows are 
likely to be smaller in 2009 than in 2008 because of the global economic crisis and heightened 
risk aversion of foreign investors. However, they are expected to rebound in 2010, as the global 
financial conditions and investor sentiment improve. Consequently, the share of FDI in total 
investment is likely to be higher than 20% in 2010.  
 
44.  The SIPRP V output target for the NPL ratio is that the ratio will not exceed 5% by 2010. 
The ratio increased from 1.5% at the end of 2007 to 2.1% at the end of 2008 because of the 
drop in stock prices, cooling of the real estate market, and slowdown in growth. The ratio is 
likely  to  increase  further  in  2009  because  of  the  anticipated  further  slowdown  of  growth. 
However, it is unlikely to exceed 5% by 2010 in part because growth is expected to rebound in 
2010. 
 
45.  Viet Nam completed the equitization of one SOCB—Vietcombank—in 2008, as part of 
an action included in the policy matrix of PRSC 7 and covered by subprogram 1 of SIPRP V. 
Furthermore,  the  Government  approved  equitization  plans  for  two  more  SOCBs—Mekong 
Housing Bank and Vietinbank—in 2008. Vietinbank had an initial public offering in December 
2008  and  the  first  general  meeting  of  shareholders  in  June  2009.  As  with  Vietcombank, 
Vietinbank's legal status has been changed from a fully state-owned company into a partially 
state-owned joint-stock company. The initial public offering of Mekong Housing Bank has been 
delayed because of unfavorable market conditions. The equitization of many SOEs has been 
delayed for the same reason. Accordingly, the progress towards the SIPRP V output targets 
pertaining to the number of SOCBs and the share of the private sector in total investment was 
slow in 2008 and the first half of 2009.  
 
46.  Viet Nam has achieved the social inclusion target related to the mortality rate for children 
under 5 years old. It is on track to attain the targets concerning the proportion of poor and ethnic 
minority people with health insurance, the number of provinces with universal completed lower 
secondary education, and the proportion of trained workers. However, the maternal mortality 
rate decreased only slightly and the net primary education enrollment rate remained stagnant 
between 2007 and 2008.   
 
47.  Viet  Nam  has  achieved  the  natural  resource  management  target  concerning  the 
proportion of the rural population with access to clean water, and is on track to attain the targets 
relating to the proportion of urban wastes that are collected. However, progress towards the 
target pertaining to the proportion of urban households with access to clean water was slow in 
2008, and the proportion of hospital waste that was treated decreased between 2007 and 2008.      
 
48.  Little progress was made towards the governance target in 2008. The non-weighted 
average  score  of  the  World  Bank's  governance  indicators  for  government  effectiveness, 
regulatory quality, rule of law, and control of corruption in Viet Nam was essentially unchanged 
between 2007 and 2008. Higher scores for government effectiveness, rule of law, and control of 
corruption were offset by a lower score for regulatory quality.  
V.  THE PROPOSED SUBPROGRAM 
A.  Policy Framework and Actions 
49.  A combined list of tentative actions under subprograms 2 and 3 was included in the 
design  and  monitoring  framework  and  the  policy  matrix  of  SIPRP  V  in  the  report  and

12 
recommendation of the President on the program cluster and its subprogram 1. These actions 
were drawn from the tentative list of policy actions for PRSCs 8–10. The report stated that, after 
the development agencies participating in the PRSC process and the Government agreed on 
the final policy matrix for PRSC 8, the actions to be covered by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V would 
be separated from those to be covered by subprogram 3. If necessary, the actions under 
subprogram 2 would be adjusted to make them fully consistent with the policy matrix for PRSC 
8.18 
 
50.  In late 2008, the development agencies participating in the PRSC process (including 
ADB) and the Government agreed on the initial policy matrix for PRSC 8.  The policy actions 
included in that matrix can be divided into the following three categories: 
 
(i)  actions that were included in the original policy matrix of SIPRP V as tentative 
actions under subprograms 2 and 3; 
(ii)  actions that were not in the original policy matrix of SIPRP V but within ADB's 
focus areas in Viet Nam; and 
(iii)  actions that were outside ADB's focus areas in Viet Nam.  
 
51.  Between  December  2008  and  May  2009,  the  development  agencies  and  the 
Government held several rounds of consultations on the actions included in the initial policy 
matrix for PRSC 8. ADB staff took part in the consultations on the actions in the first two of the 
three categories.  
 
52.  In May 2009, the development agencies and the Government agreed on the final policy 
matrix for PRSC 8. Some of the actions included in the initial matrix were modified or dropped in 
view of their status and likelihood of being completed before the World Bank's Executive Board 
considered PRSC 8 in June 2009. The final matrix includes seven actions in the first category 
and 11 actions in the second category.19 It is arguably less ambitious than the policy matrices of 
previous PRSCs. The reason is that, in the second half of 2008 and the first half of 2009, the 
Government focused on countering the adverse impacts of the global economic crisis on Viet 
Nam and could not devote enough staff resources to medium-term policy reforms. Therefore, 
development agencies anticipated the overall process of policy reforms to be relatively slow in 
2009. 
 
53.  The proposed subprogram covers all seven actions in the first category and five of the 
11 actions in the second category in the final policy matrix of PRSC 8. The actions in the second 
category have been selected in consultation with the Government and various units within ADB, 
taking into account how much progress the Government made in carrying them out and how 
important they are to ADB's operations in Viet Nam. The purpose is to recognize the substantive 
reforms that the Government implemented between June 2008 and May 2009 in consultation 
with ADB and other development agencies participating in the PRSC process. These reforms 
are within ADB's focus areas in Viet Nam, were not covered by subprogram 1 of SIPRP V, and 
are not supported by ADB's other program loans to Viet Nam.  
 
54.  The subprogram does not include a policy action on equitization of SOCBs or SOEs, 
although Viet Nam made slow progress towards the SIPRP V targets on the equitization of 
                                                
18 ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on the Proposed Program 
Cluster and Loan for Subprogram 1 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Support for the Implementation of 
the Poverty Reduction Program V. Manila (p. 21). 
19 A full list of actions included in the final policy matrix of PRSC 8 is in Appendix 5.

13 
SOCBs and the share of the domestic private sector in total investment in 2008. The reason is 
that stock prices fell sharply in 2008 and are expected to stay low in 2009. The Government 
does not want to sell shares of SOCBs and SOEs when stock prices are down. It wants to focus 
on restructuring of SOEs with the aim of improving their efficiency and selling their shares at 
higher prices when market conditions improve. Accordingly, the final policy matrix for PRSC 8 
includes an action on financial management of SOEs but no action on equitization of SOCBs or 
SOEs. 
 
55.  Most of the tentative actions under subprograms 2 and 3 in the original policy matrix of 
SIPRP V that have not been included in the policy matrix of PRSC 8 and are therefore not 
covered  by  subprogram  2  of  SIPRP  V  have  been  retained  as  tentative  actions  under  its 
subprogram 3. In the second half of 2008 and the first half of 2009, the Government made some 
progress in carrying out several of these actions (e.g., transferring state ownership rights in 
SOEs to the State Capital Investment Corporation, equitizing SOCBs, and certifying internal 
credit  rating  systems  of  commercial  banks).  However,  the  progress  was  not  sufficient  to 
consider  the  actions  completed.  The  Government  and  development  agencies  are  likely  to 
continue dialogue on these actions in conjunction with PRSC 9. Therefore, they have been 
retained as tentative actions under subprogram 3 of SIPRP V. Figure A3.2 in Appendix 3 is the 
updated policy matrix of SIPRP V. 
 
56.  Some of the tentative actions under subprograms 2 and 3 in the original policy matrix of 
SIPRP V have been dropped or replaced with other actions in the same reform area. Notably, 
the  actions  concerning  the  establishment  of  a  national  business  registry  and  the  legal 
framework for the development of small and medium-sized enterprises have been dropped. The 
Government made some progress in carrying out these actions in the second half of 2008 and 
the first half of 2009, but it was not sufficient to regard the actions as completed. They will be 
covered by the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Program Loan II (included in ADB's 
2009 indicative pipeline for Viet Nam). Table A3.1 in Appendix 3 shows the status of each 
tentative action under subprograms 2 and 3 in the original policy matrix of SIPRP V and 
indicates why some of them have been dropped or replaced.  
 
57.  The changes in the policy matrix of SIPRP V are not expected to have a major impact on 
its outcome. They slightly increase the likelihood that the SIPRP V output targets for natural 
resource management and governance will be achieved. At the same time, they slightly reduce 
the chances that the SIPRP V output targets related to the number of SOCBs and health will be 
attained. In terms of overall business development, the measures aimed at restructuring SOEs 
will compensate for the relatively slow progress in their equitization.  
 
58.  All actions covered by the proposed subprogram have been completed, although two of 
them—action 1.2 (prepare a revised law on the central bank focusing its mandate on, and 
enhancing its autonomy in regard to, monetary policy and financial sector stability) and action 
4.2 (formulate a public debt management law consolidating the management of domestic and 
external  debt)—have  not  been  carried  out  exactly  as  envisaged.  The  Government's 
Development Policy Letter is in Appendix 6.  
1.  Business Development 
59.  Action 1.1: Strengthen financial management of SOEs, limiting their investments 
in other entities, defining the level of such investments.20 Many SOEs invested extensively 
                                                
20 The action is one of the tentative actions under subprograms 2 and 3 in the original policy matrix of SIPRP V.

14 
in non-core businesses, including financial and real estate companies, in recent years. Their 
aggressive  investment  expansion  contributed  to  the  stock  market  bubble  in  2007  and  the 
macroeconomic turbulence in 2008. Close links between some SOEs and commercial banks 
created the risk that the banks' lending decisions would not be guided solely by commercial 
considerations. As a result, the allocation of credit could be distorted, the quality of banks' loan 
portfolio could worsen, and the vulnerability of the banking system could increase.  
 
60.  To  address  these  issues,  the  Government  has  adopted—through  Decree  No. 
09/2009/ND-CP dated 5 February 2009—a new regulation on financial management of SOEs. 
The regulation limits SOEs' investments in non-core businesses, especially in the financial 
sector. It stipulates that an SOE must invest at least 70% of its capital and borrowed funds in 
core businesses. Total investments of an SOE in other companies should not exceed its charter 
capital.  An  SOE  can  only  invest  in  one  company  operating  in  the  banking,  insurance,  or 
securities subsectors, and its investment cannot exceed 20% of that company's charter capital. 
If an SOE and its subsidiary invest in the same company, their combined investment cannot 
exceed  30%  of  that  company's  charter  capital.  An  SOE  is  prohibited  from  investing  in  a 
company whose senior staff member or major shareholder is related to a senior staff member of 
the SOE.   
 
61.  This action under subprogram 2 builds on action 1.1 under subprogram 1 (assess the 
scope and nature of lending and other transactions among affiliated parties within economic 
groups and general corporations). It provides an impetus to restructure SOEs and complements 
the reforms that the SOE Reform and Corporate Governance Facility, a program loan in ADB’s 
2009 indicative pipeline for Viet Nam, is intended to support.  
 
62.  Action 1.2: Prepare a revised law on the central bank focusing its mandate on, and 
enhancing  its  autonomy  in  regard  to,  monetary  policy  and  financial  sector  stability 
(footnote 20). The current Law on the State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV), the country's central bank, 
assigns the SBV numerous tasks, including those not usually performed by a central bank (such 
as  regulating  the  gold  market).  At  the  same  time,  it  gives  the  SBV  limited  autonomy  in 
formulating monetary policy. The law assigns an important role in monetary policy formulation to 
the Advisory Board on National Monetary Policy, chaired by one of the deputy prime ministers. 
Furthermore, the law sets multiple (potentially conflicting) goals for monetary policy without 
prioritization. These goals include stabilizing the value of the currency, controlling inflation, 
facilitating socioeconomic development, ensuring national defense and security, and improving 
living standards.   
 
63.  In consultation with development agencies, the Government is preparing a revised law 
on  the  SBV.  The  latest  draft  of  the  law  incorporates  many  of  the  comments  made  by 
development  agencies  on  its  earlier  draft.  It  makes  the  SBV's  mandate  more  focused  on 
monetary  policy  and  financial  sector  stability,  and  increases  its  autonomy  in  formulating 
monetary policy. In particular, the draft law does not provide for the Advisory Board on the 
National Monetary Policy. Instead, it gives the SBV governor the power to establish a committee 
on monetary policy within the SBV. It also sets one objective for monetary policy—ensuring the 
stability of the value of the currency, which encompasses controlling inflation and preventing 
sharp fluctuations of the exchange rate. However, for a number of country-specific reasons, the 
Government has decided that the National Assembly (parliament) should retain the authority to 
approve  inflation  targets  (proposed  by  the  SBV),  and  the  SBV  governor  should  continue 
reporting to the Prime Minister rather than directly to the National Assembly. The draft law is 
expected to be presented to the National Assembly for discussion in the fourth quarter of 2009 
and for approval in the second quarter of 2010.

15 
 
64.  Action  1.2  under  the  proposed  subprogram  will  help  strengthen  monetary  policy 
management,  control  inflation,  and  enhance  financial  sector  stability.  It  complements 
improvements  in  the  monetary  policy  framework  that  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
strengthening monetary policy management (included in the indicative pipeline for 2010) is 
intended to bring about. It also complements policy actions and reforms under subprogram 1 of 
the Third Financial Sector Program Loan (approved in November 2007)21 and activities of the 
TA for Support for Developing Capital Markets and Building Capacity in the Financial Sector 
(approved in June 2008).22 
 
65.  Action 1.3: Make commercial-scale infringements of patents, trademark rights, 
and rights of design a crime.23 Although Viet Nam has a Law on Intellectual Property Rights, 
the protection of intellectual property rights is weak, which stifles innovation and business 
development.  Companies  that  participated  in  the  business  environment  sentiment  survey 
conducted by the Vietnam Business Forum in October 2008 ranked the weak protection of 
intellectual property rights as the second-worst aspect of the business environment in Viet Nam 
after infrastructure.24  
 
66.  One reason violations of intellectual property rights are common in Viet Nam is that such 
violations are not considered a crime in the country's Criminal Code. To rectify this situation, the 
Government has prepared—in consultations with development agencies—amendments to the 
Criminal Code that make commercial-scale infringement of patents, trademark rights, and rights 
of design a crime. The amendments were approved by the National Assembly in June 2009 and 
will become effective on 1 January 2010. 
 
67.  This  action  under  the  proposed  subprogram  complements  policy  actions  that  are 
supported by subprogram 2 of the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Program Loan 
(approved  in  December  2006)25 as  well  as  actions that the  Small  and Medium  Enterprise 
Development Program Loan II (included in the indicative pipeline for 2009) is intended to 
support. It will contribute to business development and the successful implementation of SEDP 
2006–2010 by promoting private sector development. 
 
68.  Action  1.4:  Adopt  a  pricing  system  for  electricity  from  renewable  energy  and 
provide incentives for government procurement of energy-efficient equipment (footnote 
20). To meet rapidly growing demand for electricity while protecting the environment, Viet Nam 
needs to increase power generation from renewable energy and stimulate the production of 
energy-efficient machinery and equipment. However, the cost of generating electricity from 
renewable energy is often higher than the cost of generating it from non-renewable resources 
(such as coal and gas). Therefore, prices for electricity generated from renewable energy must 
be higher than those for electricity generated from non-renewable resources to make power 
generation from renewable energy financially viable.

69.  In  July  2008,  the  Ministry  of  Industry  and  Trade  approved—through  Decision  No. 
18/2008/QD-BCT—the  Regulations  on  Avoided  Cost  and  Standardized  Power  Purchase 
Agreement for Small Power Producers of Renewable Energy. The regulations stipulate that the 
wholsale price of electricity from renewable energy should be based on the weighted average 
cost of electricity produced by combined-cycle gas turbines, which are the most costly thermal 
units in Viet Nam's electricity supply system. This pricing system, which became effective on 1 
January 2009, has made the production of electricity from renewable energy commercially more 
attractive. It has significantly improved the chances that ADB's Renewable Energy Development 
and Network Expansion and Rehabilitation for Remote Communes Sector Project (approved in 
March 2009)26 will be successful.  
 
70.  In March 2009, the Government decided to take additional measures aimed at ensuring 
the full and timely implementation of the national program on energy efficiency (adopted in 
2008). One of these measures is to provide incentives for government procurement of energy-
efficient  equipment  (e.g.,  by  providing  government  agencies  with  additional  funds  for 
procurement of energy-efficient equipment and allowing them to retain savings on electricity bills 
arising from the use of such equipment).  
 
71.  Action 1.4 under the proposed subprogram will provide an impetus to develop renewable 
energy and use energy-efficient equipment in Viet Nam. In so doing, it will help improve the 
quality of infrastructure, protect the environment, and help reduce poverty indirectly by fostering 
environmentally sustainable economic growth.  
 
72.  The action will also contribute to poverty reduction directly. Some of the areas with high 
incidence of poverty (e.g., mountainous areas inhabited by ethnic minorities) have significant 
untapped renewable energy resources. The new pricing system for electricity from renewable 
energy will help expand the production of such electricity in these areas. Producers of electricity 
from renewable energy will be able to compensate for the relatively high cost of production and 
the low purchasing power of the local population by supplying surplus electricity to the national 
grid at higher prices. The expansion of electricity production will improve remote communes' 
access to  electricity, foster  business  development,  create  jobs,  raise  living  standards,  and 
reduce poverty in these communes.27 
2.  Social Inclusion 
73.  Action 2.1: Formulate an education development strategy for the period up to 2020, 
focusing on the equity of learning outcomes and the relevance of contents (footnote 20). 
Although Viet Nam's education sector improved substantially in the last 10–15 years, many 
issues remain. In particular, the primary education enrollment rate remained stagnant between 
2007 and 2008 (Appendix 4). Furthermore, learning outcomes and completion rates in primary 
education differ significantly among various groups of children. Children from poor households 
tend to do less well than children from non-poor households; children in remote areas tend to do 
less well than children in other areas; and ethnic minority children tend to do less well than 
ethnic majority children. The completion rates for children from the poorest income quintile and 
ethnic minority children are about 20 percentage points lower than those for children from the 
                                                
26 ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Renewable Energy Development and 
Network Expansion and Rehabilitation for Remote Communes Sector Project. Manila. 
27 Communes are the third-level administrative units (below provinces and districts) in Viet Nam.

17 
richest income quintile and ethnic majority children, respectively.28 The relevance of contents is 
an issue at the higher levels of education, especially in vocational and university education. 
There are also small gender disparities in education, with a higher proportion of boys in primary 
and secondary education and a higher proportion of girls in vocational and university education.  
 
74.  To address these issues in a holistic manner, the Government has prepared—through 
extensive consultations within the Government, as well as with the civil society, development 
agencies, and other stakeholders—an education development strategy for the period up to 
2020. Unlike previous education strategies, which focused on certain levels of education, the 
new strategy takes a comprehensive approach to education development. It covers all levels of 
education from early childhood to higher education, and attaches particular importance to the 
equity of leaning outcomes and the relevance of contents. It is expected to be adopted together 
with SEDP 2011–2020 in 2010.  
 
75.  The  strategy  will  provide  a  medium-term framework for the  Secondary  Education 
Sector Development Program (included in the indicative pipeline for 2009) and the Higher 
Education  Sector  Development  Program  (included  in  the  indicative  pipeline  for  2010). 
Ultimately, it will help improve access to and the quality of education, enhance Viet Nam's 
competitiveness, eliminate the remaining gender disparities in education, and foster socially 
inclusive economic growth. 
3.  Natural Resource Management 
76.  Action  3.1:  Issue  regulations  to  ensure  financial  sustainability  of  irrigation 
services and provide financial relief for poor farmers (footnote 23). The incidence of poverty 
among farmers, especially rice-growing farmers, is significantly higher than among non-farmers. 
The household survey data show that the poverty rate was 20.4% among farmers and 23.4% 
among rice-growing farmers in 2006, compared with 3.8% for the urban population and 5.0% for 
non-farmers living in the rural areas.29 Because of their low incomes, many poor farmers are 
unable to pay for the water they use in crop production.   
 
77.  In October 2007, the Government issued Decree No. 154/2007/ND-CP, which called for 
the abolition of irrigation service fees with the aim of providing financial relief to poor farmers. 
However,  the  irrigation  service  fee  waiver  envisaged  in  the  decree  was  poorly  targeted. 
Furthermore, the decree raised concerns about the financial viability of irrigation services, the 
sustainability  of  investment  in  irrigation  infrastructure,  and  the  lack  of  incentives  for  water 
conservation.  
 
78.  To address these concerns, the Government issued Decree No. 115/2008/ND-CP dated 
14  November  2008,  which  clarifies  the  application  of  the  irrigation  service  fee  waver  and 
assigns responsibilities for financing operation and maintenance of irrigation infrastructure. The 
decree stipulates that the irrigation service fee waiver applies only to services provided by 
irrigation management companies (which are SOEs) and only to water used for agricultural

production  up  to  a  certain  limit.30 Only  farmers  with  arable  land  of  up  to  1–2  hectares 
(depending on the locality) are eligible for the waiver (with the size of arable land serving as a 
proxy for a farmer's income). The decree also requires the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and local 
governments  to  provide  adequate  financial  support  from  the  central  and  local  budgets  to 
irrigation management companies to enable them to properly operate and maintain irrigation 
infrastructure. The MOF issued Circular No. 36/2009/TT-BTC dated 26 February 2009 on the 
implementation of the decree and increased the budget allocation for irrigation subsidies from 
D1.0 trillion in 2008 to D3.5 trillion in 2009.  
 
79.  Action 3.1 under subprogram 2 addresses an important policy issue affecting ADB's 
several ongoing and planned projects in Viet Nam, including the Second Red River Basin 
Sector Project (approved in October 2001),31 Phuoc Hoa Water Resources Project (approved in 
November 2003),32 Central Region Water Resources Project (approved in November 2005,)33 
and  the  Strengthening  Water  Management  and  Irrigation  Systems  Rehabilitation  Project 
(included  in  the  2010  indicative  pipeline  for  lending  products).  It  will  contribute  to  poverty 
reduction directly by providing financial relief to poor farmers and indirectly by improving the 
management of water resources and fostering environmentally sustainable economic growth. 
Tentative action 3.1 under subprogram 3 (issue guidelines for efficient use of water resources to 
accompany the irrigation service fee waiver policy) will build on action 3.1 under subprogram 2 
to address the issue of inadequate incentives for water conservation, another important policy 
issue affecting ADB's operations in Viet Nam.  
 
80.  Action 3.2: Approve a national targeted program for adapting to climate change 
and  allocate  institutional  responsibilities  for  its  implementation (footnote 20). Climate 
change is expected to have significant adverse impacts on Viet Nam. A study on potential 
consequences of rising sea levels resulting from climate change for 84 developing countries 
found that Viet Nam is one of the five countries that would be most severely affected.34 A sea 
level rise of 1 meter would affect more than 5% of Viet Nam's land area and almost 11% of its 
population. An analysis of the potential impact of climate change on human development in Viet 
Nam concluded that climate  change  is  "a  very  real threat  to  Viet  Nam's  continued  socio-
economic development."35  
 
81.  To meet  the  challenges  posed  by  climate change,  the  Government has  adopted—
through  Decision  No.  158/2008/QD-TTg  dated  2  December  2008—the  National  Targeted 
Program  for  Responding  to  the  Climate  Change.  The  objectives  of  the  program  include 
assessing  the  impacts  of  climate  change  on  specific  sectors  and  localities  in  Viet  Nam; 
increasing public awareness of the challenges posed by climate change; and developing and 
implementing national, sector-specific, and local action plans to respond to climate change.

83.  Action 3.3: Enhance treatment of medical waste discharged by hospitals at both 
central and local levels (footnote 23). The proportion of hospital wastes that were treated 
declined between 2007 and 2008. Therefore, the treatment of hospital wastes was one of the 
subjects  covered  during  the  consultations  between  the  Government  and  the  development 
agencies on the policy matrix for PRSC 8.    
 
84.  In October 2008, the Ministry of Health issued Directive No. 7164/BYT-KCB, instructing 
all hospitals to set up a system for treatment of medical wastes. In January 2009, a steering 
committee on the treatment of medical wastes, chaired by minister of health, was established. 
The Ministry of Health is now preparing an action plan for improving the treatment of hospital 
wastes, including solid and liquid wastes. The action plan will cover public and private hospitals. 
 
85.  This action under the proposed subprogram complements the Health Care in the South 
Central  Coast  Region  Project  (approved  in  October  2008),  which  aims  to  improve  health 
facilities and hospital waste management in the south central coast region of Viet Nam.36 It will 
help protect the environment and eliminate the risk to public safety posed by medical wastes.   
4.  Governance 
86.  Action 4.1: Conduct a midterm review of SEDP 2006–2010 and strengthen the 
results-based  approach  in  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  framework  for  planning 
(footnote 23). As part of the modernization of planning processes in Viet Nam, the Government 
adopted a results-based monitoring and evaluation framework for SEDP 2006–2010 in 2007.37 
ADB assisted the Government in developing the framework through the TA for Results-Based 
Monitoring of Poverty Reduction and Growth (approved in July 2005).38 Although SEDP 2006–
2010 calls for improvements in many aspects of governance, only a few indicators and targets 
for monitoring and evaluating progress in this area were included in the framework because of 
the lack of suitable indicators. 
 
87.  In 2008, the Government prepared a midterm review of SEDP 2006–2010, using the 
results-based monitoring and evaluation framework adopted in 2007. Unlike the Government's 
previous reports on the implementation of SEDPs, the midterm review of SEDP 2006–2010 
focused on progress towards development outcomes rather than production targets. The review 
was  presented  to  the  National  Assembly  in  October  2008  and  to  the  Consultative  Group 
Meeting for Viet Nam in December 2008. It was useful in assessing the progress towards 
performance targets of SIPRP V (which are aligned with those of SEDP 2006–2010) and

88.  Furthermore, the Government conducted a pilot survey on governance in conjunction 
with the Viet Nam household living standards survey 2008. The survey results, which are being 
analyzed, will be used in developing governance indicators for monitoring and evaluation of the 
implementation of future SEDPs and in designing a governance module for future household 
living standards surveys.  
 
89.  Action  4.2:  Formulate  a  public  debt  management  law  consolidating  the 
management of domestic and external debt (footnote 20). Viet Nam has made considerable 
progress in modernizing its tax system and improving public expenditure management over the 
past several years. However, progress in strengthening the management of public assets and 
liabilities has been slow. In particular, the legal framework for public debt management has 
remained  weak.  The  responsibility  for  managing  public  debt  is  divided  among  several 
government agencies (including the MOF) and among several units within the MOF. Information 
sharing  among  the  government  agencies  responsible  for  managing  public  debt  is  not 
satisfactory.  
 
90.  In an important step towards sound public debt management, the Government has 
formulated—in  consultation  with  development  agencies—a  law  on  public  debt.  The  law 
consolidates to a large degree the management of domestic and external public debt in one 
department  within  the  MOF  and  improves  information  sharing  among  the  MOF  and  other 
government agencies that will, for historical reasons, continue playing a role in public debt 
management.39  The law was passed by the National Assembly in June 2009 and will become 
effective on 1 January 2010.  
 
91.  Action 4.2 under subprogram 2 will help strengthen public financial management and 
improve  governance  in  Viet  Nam.  It  complements  activities  of  the  TA  for  the  Support  for 
Developing Capital Markets and Building Capacity in the Financial Sector (footnote 22) and the 
TA for Supporting Financial Management Decentralization (approved in December 2007).40  
 
92.  Action 4.3: Adopt principles of competition, merit-orientation, and transparency in 
the recruitment, appointment, promotion, and dismissal of civil servants (footnote 23). 
The recruitment and promotion of civil servants are not always competitive, merit-based, and 
transparent. It is one of the main reasons why public administration is weak and corruption is a 
serious problem. 
 
93.  In November 2008, the National Assembly passed the Law on Civil Servants, which will 
become effective on 1 January 2010. The law introduces the principles of competition, merit-
orientation, and transparency in the recruitment, appointment, promotion, and dismissal of civil 
servants. ADB assisted the Government in drafting the law through the TA for Supporting Civil 
Service Reform (approved in August 2008).41
