94.  The Ministry of Home Affairs has adopted an action plan for the implementation of the 
law. The plan includes drafting the necessary implementing regulations and conducting pilot civil 
service projects, which ADB will support through the TA on civil service reform (para. 93). These 
activities have been included in the updated policy matrix of SIPRP V as tentative action 4.5 
under subprogram 3.      
 
95.  Action 4.4: Issue a comprehensive anticorruption strategy, setting out preventive, 
demand-side,  and  sector-specific  solutions,  and  monitoring  mechanisms. 42  The 
Government  recognizes  that  corruption  is  a  major  hindrance  to  the  country's  economic 
development. As part of its effort to reduce corruption, the Government has adopted—through 
Resolution No. 21/NQ-CP dated 12 May 2009—a national anticorruption strategy for the period 
up to 2020 and an action plan for the implementation of the strategy. The strategy provides for a 
wide  range  of  measures  to  combat  corruption,  including  preventive  measures  (such  as 
enhancing the transparency of policy making and creating equal opportunities for all businesses) 
and demand-side measures (such as adopting a law on access to information and narrowing 
the range of information that is considered to be a state secret). The strategy also calls for the 
development of sector-specific and provincial plans for its implementation. The action plan 
includes developing indicators for assessing progress in fighting corruption, conducting annual 
household  and  enterprise  surveys  on  unofficial  payments  to  government  agencies,  and 
disclosing survey results.  
B.  Financing Plan 
96.  Some of the policy actions covered by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V entail substantial costs 
to Viet Nam’s state budget. Some of the actions included in the policy matrix for PRSC 8 but not 
covered by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V also have significant costs. For example, ensuring 
financial sustainability of irrigation services, while providing financial relief to poor farmers, will 
cost the state budget about $170 million in 2008, $190 million in 2009, $210 million in 2011. The 
implementation  of  the  National  Targeted  Program  for  Adapting  to  the  Climate  Change 
(excluding the national, sector-specific, and local actions plans) will cost more than $100 million, 
half of which is to be provided from the state budget. The implementation of the national, sector-
specfic, and local action plans is likely to cost the state budget billions of dollars. The total cost 
to the state budget in 2009–2011 of the actions included in the policy matrix for PRSC 8 is 
estimated at $680 million.  
 
97.  The  Government  has  requested  development  agencies  participating  in  the  PRSC 
process to finance a greater share of the cost of policy reforms in 2009 than in the previous 
years.  The  reason  is  that  the  Government  is  facing  difficulties  in  financing  its  increased 
expenditure on social safety nets. Budgetary revenue is expected to decline considerably in 
2009 compared with 2008 mostly because of lower world oil prices, lower foreign trade turnover, 
and tax reductions and deferrals aimed at stimulating growth. At the same time, the cost of 
borrowing in financial markets has increased substantially because of the global economic crisis 
and investors' heightened aversion to risk.  
 
98.  It is proposed that a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR64,036,000 be provided 
for subprogram 2 of SIPRP V from ADB’s Special Funds resources. The loan will have a term of 
24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; an annual interest rate of 1.0% during the grace

C.  Implementation Arrangements44 
1.  Executing Agency 
100.  The SBV is the Executing Agency for SIPRP V. As such, it will be the Executing Agency 
for the proposed subprogram.  
 
101.  The SBV hosts the PRSC coordination unit, which facilitates interactions between the 
Government and development agencies within the framework of the PRSC process. The SBV 
was also the Executing Agency for SIPRPs I–IV.  
2.  Disbursement and Procurement 
102.  The proposed loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon the declaration of loan 
effectiveness.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs 
(excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, 
excluding the ineligible items listed in Appendix 8 and imports financed from other bilateral and 
multilateral sources. 
 
103.  As provided in ADB’s simplified disbursement procedures and requirements for program 
loans,45 the proceeds of the loan will be disbursed to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam as the 
Borrower. No supporting import documentation will be required, provided that the value of 
Viet Nam’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports financed under other official development assistance is at least equal to the amount of 
the loan to be disbursed. The Government will certify its compliance with this formula with its 
withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be 
required. ADB will have the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy 
of the Borrower’s certification. The Borrower's procedures for procurement and disbursement of 
funds, and the use of counterpart funds, are considered satisfactory. 
3.  Period of Utilization 
104.  The loan will be fully utilized by 31 May 2010.

4.  Anticorruption Policy 
105.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to subprogram 2 of SIPRP V. To 
support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the draft 
Loan Agreement. 
VI.  SUBPROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACT, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic and Financial Benefits 
106.  The policy reforms supported by SIPRP V and, in particular, its subprogram 2 will yield 
considerable  economic  benefits  to  Viet  Nam  and  substantial  financial  benefits  to  the 
Government. They will raise the living standards of the Vietnamese people by fostering socially 
inclusive and environmentally sustainable economic growth. The reforms will also increase 
budget revenue by expanding the tax base, and reduce budget expenditure by improving public 
financial management. Over the medium term, the financial benefits of these reforms to the 
Government are likely to exceed their costs (including interest to be paid on loans received from 
development agencies within the framework of the PRSC process). 
B.  Social Impact 
107.  A detailed poverty and social impact assessment of subprogram 2 of SIPRP V has been 
prepared.  In  particular,  the  social  implications  of  the  actions  covered  by  the  subprogram 
(including  their  indigenous  people  and  involuntary  resettlement  implications)  have  been 
reviewed. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 9. 
 
108.  The policy actions covered by the subprogram will have significant social effects. In 
particular, they will help reduce poverty indirectly by improving governance and the quality of 
education, developing businesses, and spurring economic growth. Business development and 
economic growth will create news jobs, raise incomes, and make more resources available for 
social protection. The poor will benefit from new jobs, higher incomes, and increased availability 
of resources for social protection.  
 
109.  Some of the actions under the subprogram will also make a direct contribution to poverty 
reduction. For example, action 1.4 (adopt a pricing system for electricity from renewable energy 
and provide incentives for government procurement of energy-efficient equipment) will help 
reduce poverty in areas with untapped renewable energy resources and high incidence of 
poverty (e.g., mountainous areas inhabited by ethnic minorities) by making the production of 
electricity  from  renewable  energy  commercially  more  attractive.  Action  2.1  (formulate  an 
education development strategy for the period up to 2020, focusing on the equity of learning 
outcomes and the relevance of contents) will help improve access of the poor, ethnic minorities 
and other disadvantaged groups of the population to education and ensure that there are no 
significant  differences  in  learning  outcomes  among  children  of  different  backgrounds  (i.e., 
children from poor households do as well as children from rich households, children in remote 
areas do as well as children in other areas, and ethnic minority children do as well as ethnic 
majority  children).  This  action  will  also  help  eliminate  the  remaining  gender  disparities  in 
education. Action 3.1 (issue regulations aimed to ensure financial sustainability of irrigation 
services  and  provide  financial  relief  for  poor  farmers)  will  make  irrigation  services  more

24 
affordable for poor farmers. Farm households headed by women will benefit more from this 
action than farm households headed by men, because the incidence of poverty among the 
former is higher than among the latter. Action 4.1 (conduct a midterm review of SEDP 2006–
2010 and strengthen the result-based approach in the monitoring and evaluation framework for 
planning) will help make future SEDPs more effective in reducing poverty and addressing 
gender issues.  
 
110.  Ethnic minorities will benefit more from the policy actions covered by the subprogram 
than the ethnic majority. However, none of the actions is centered on ethnic minorities or has an 
adverse  impact  on  ethnic  minorities.  Therefore,  the  subprogram  has  been  assigned  to 
indigenous people category C. 
 
111.  SIPRP V does not have an investment component, and the policy actions covered by its 
subprogram 2 will not cause any involuntary resettlement. Hence, the subprogram has been 
assigned to involuntary resettlement category C. 
C.  Environmental Impact 
112.  Subprogram  2  of  SIPRP  V  has  been  assigned  to  environmental  category  C.  Its 
environmental implications have been reviewed and a matrix of potential environmental impacts 
has been prepared in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). The matrix is in 
Appendix 10. 
 
113.  The review of the environmental implications of subprogram 2 concluded that several of 
the actions included in the policy framework for this subprogram are likely to have at least minor 
positive environmental impact. For example, the adoption of the National Targeted Program on 
Adapting to the Climate Change is likely to have a major positive impact, while the actions 
related to renewable energy, irrigation services, and medical wastes are likely to have minor 
positive  impact.  Enhancement  measures  have  been  developed  to  optimize  the  expected 
positive impact. No action has been identified as likely to have an adverse environmental impact. 
D.  Assumptions and Risks 
114.  SIPRP V and, in particular, its subprogram 2 are to support policy actions that constitute 
critical steps in the policy reforms needed for the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–
2010 and are important to ADB’s operations in Viet Nam. However, the reforms need to be fully 
carried out if SEDP 2006–2010 is to be successfully implemented. Therefore, it is assumed that, 
after completing the policy actions covered by SIPRP V and the other actions included in the 
policy matrices for the World Bank’s PRSCs 7–9, the Government will follow through with the 
policy reforms needed for the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010 on its own or with 
the  support  of  development  agencies  under  other  projects.  It  is  further  assumed  that  the 
investment projects that are included in SEDP 2006–2010 and necessary for attaining its targets 
and goals will be implemented on schedule.  
 
115.  These assumptions are based on the Government’s commitment to carry out the policy 
reforms and implement the investment projects that are needed to achieve the targets and goals 
of  SEDP  2006–2010.  Furthermore,  policy  reforms  that  are  needed  for  the  successful 
implementation  of  SEDP  2006–2010  are  now  or  will  be  supported  by  ADB  through  other 
policy-based loans to Viet Nam (such as the financial sector program loans and the small and 
medium-sized enterprise development loans) and by other development agencies both within 
and outside the framework of the PRSC process.

25 
 
116.  The slowdown of growth caused by the global economic crisis could be so prolonged 
that it will preclude the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010 and, in particular, the 
achievement of its poverty target. However, this risk is small. The fiscal stimulus measures 
adopted by the Government in January–May 2009 will spur growth in the second half of 2009 
and in 2010. Moreover, the external environment is expected to improve significantly in 2010. 
Accordingly, economic growth is likely to rebound in the second half of 2009 and accelerate 
further in 2010.  
 
117.  As economic growth accelerates and world commodity prices rise, inflation could surge 
again. High inflation could push many households into poverty and preclude the successful 
implementation of SEDP 2006-2010. To mitigate this risk, the SBV has started taking measures 
to keep inflation in check. In particular, it has committed to limit growth of money supply to 30% 
in 2009; asked state-owned commercial banks to limit loan growth to 25% in 2009; and urged all 
commercial banks to tighten credit for consumer spending and purchases of real estate and 
stocks. The SBV is expected to start tightening monetary policy toward the end of 2009 and 
pursue moderately tight monetary policy in 2010.46 
VII.  ASSURANCES 
118.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the draft loan agreement: 
 
(i)  The  actions  covered  by  subprogram  2  of  SIPRP  V  and  specified  in  the 
Development Policy Letter will continue to be in effect during the implementation 
of SEDP 2006–2010 and thereafter; and 
(ii)  Adequate and timely counterpart funds for carrying out these actions will be 
made available. 
VIII.  RECOMMENDATION 
119.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 64,036,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet 
Nam for subprogram 2 of the Support for the Implementation of the Poverty Reduction Program 
V from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 24 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

32  Appendix 2   
SECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Recent Progress in Poverty Reduction in Viet Nam 
1.  Viet Nam made remarkable progress in poverty reduction in the past 15–20 years. The 
most recent available household survey data show that the poverty rate (based on the cost of a 
consumption basket allowing for a daily intake of 2,100 calories per person and some nonfood 
expenditure)  dropped  from  58.1%  in  1993  to  16.0%  in  2006.  The  food  poverty  rate  (the 
proportion of people whose total expenditure would not suffice for a daily intake of 2,100 
calories even if it was entirely allocated to food) fell from 24.9% to 6.7% between 1993 and 
2006. The poverty gap (the difference between the poverty line and the average expenditure of 
the poor expressed as a percentage of the former) narrowed from 18.5% to 3.8% over the same 
period (Table A2.1).

2.  Measures of poverty not based on household survey data point to declines of similar 
magnitudes in poverty, although they give different levels of poverty. The proportion of people 
living on less than $1.0 a day based on purchasing power parity (PPP) dropped from 50.8% of 
the population in 1990 to 4.0% in 2007, and the proportion of those living on less than $2.0 per 
day based on PPP fell from 87.0% to 32.9% (Table A2.2). The poverty rate based on the 
methodology of the Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA) fell from 22.0% in 
2005 to an estimated 13.1% in 2008.1 
                                                
1 The poverty rate based on the methodology of the MOLISA measures the proportion of people living below the 
official poverty line, which is D260,000 per person in urban areas and D200,000 per person in rural areas. 
Households below the poverty line are identified by local officials of MOLISA through a combination of their 
personal knowledge, survey techniques, and village discussions.

3.  Accordingly, Viet Nam has made good progress toward the Millennium Development 
Goals (MDGs). It has achieved three MDG targets and is likely to attain another four ahead of 
time. In addition to the targets for extreme poverty and hunger, Viet Nam has achieved the 
target concerning the incidence of malaria and other diseases. The country is likely to achieve 
the  targets  for  the  completion  of  primary  schooling  by  boys  and  girls,  gender  equality  in 
education, under-5 mortality, and maternal mortality (Table A2.3). 
B.  Challenges in Poverty Reduction 
4.  Despite the tremendous strides Viet Nam has made in eradicating poverty over the past 
15–20 years, much remains to be done. First, the absolute number of poor people is still large, 
although their share in the total population has been drastically reduced. The household survey 
data show that 13.5 million people lived in poverty and 5.7 million people suffered from hunger 
in 2006. The poverty rate based on MOLISA's methodology suggests that 11.3 million people 
lived below the official poverty line in 2008. According to the World Bank, 3.4 million people 
survived on less than $1.0 per day (based on PPP) and 28.1 million people lived on less than 
$2.0 per day (based on PPP) in 2007 (Table A2.2). 
 
5.  Second, the incidence of poverty is still high in rural areas and among ethnic minorities, 
even though it has been decreasing faster than in urban areas and among the ethnic majority. 
In 2006, the poverty rate was 20.4% in rural areas (compared with 3.9% in urban areas), and 
52.2% among ethnic minorities (compared with 10.2% among the Kinh and Chinese majority) 
(Table A2.1). Rural areas accounted for 73.3% of the total population but 93.6% of the poor. 
Ethnic minorities made up only 13.5% of the total population but 44.4% of the poor (Table A2.4).

6.  Third, the rural poor and poor ethnic minority people not only account for relatively large 
proportions of their respective population groups, but also have significantly lower average 
incomes than the urban poor and poor ethnic majority people, respectively. In 2006, the poverty 
gap was 4.9% in the rural areas and 15.4% among ethnic minorities, compared with 3.2% in the 
urban areas and 2.0% among the Kinh and Chinese majority (Table A2.4).

8.  Fifth, the vulnerability of the population to poverty is rather high. The large difference 
between the proportion of the population living on less than $2.0 a day based on PPP (32.9% in 
2007) and the share of those living on less than $1.0 a day based on PPP (4.0% in 2007) 
suggests that the near-poor account for a substantial proportion of the population. A small 
external or internal shock and a moderate deterioration in the economic situation could push 
many of these people into poverty.

36  Appendix 2   
9.  Finally, some negative trends in poverty have emerged recently. The household survey 
data show that urban poverty increased between 2004 and 2006, with the poverty rate rising 
from 3.6% in 2004 to 3.9% in 2006, and the food poverty rate increasing from 0.8% to 1.2%. 
Anecdotal evidence suggests that high inflation and, in particular, the steep rise of food prices 
pushed many low-income households, especially in urban areas, into poverty in 2008. As 
economic activity slowed sharply, unemployment increased and more households, particularly 
in rural areas, fell into poverty in the first several months of 2009. Many people from rural areas 
who were employed in urban areas of Viet Nam or abroad lost their jobs and stopped sending 
remittances to their households. Some of them returned to their villages, even though they had 
few alternative sources of income there.    
C.  Policy Framework for Poverty Reduction  
10.  Robust economic growth has been the key driver of poverty reduction in Viet Nam, but 
government policies and targeted programs have played a major role in making that growth 
pro-poor.  The  Government’s  current  poverty  reduction  strategy  is  embedded  in  the 
Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010.  
 
1.  Socioeconomic Development Plan 2006–2010.  
 
11.  The Government adopted SEDP 2006–2010 in 2006. Unlike previous SEDPs, it was 
prepared  in  an  open  and  participatory  manner  involving  extensive  consultations  with  civil 
society,  businesses,  and  development  agencies,  and  is  oriented  more  toward  attaining 
development  outcomes  (including  poverty  reduction)  and  less  toward  achieving  production 
targets. Its targets include a reduction in the poverty rate (based on MOLISA’s methodology) 
from 22% in 2005 to 10%–11% in 2010. SEDP 2006–2010 also aspires to strengthen the 
foundations  for  environmentally  sustainable  and  socially  inclusive  economic  growth  and  a 
continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. It provides for a broad range of policy reforms and 
a large number of investment projects aimed at achieving its targets and goals. The joint 
International  Development  Association–International  Monetary  Fund  staff  advisory  note  of 
5 December 2006 on Viet Nam’s poverty reduction strategy concluded that SEDP 2006–2010 
has the key features of a poverty reduction strategy and is likely to lead to economic growth and 
poverty reduction.2 
2.  Social Protection and Targeted Programs for Poverty Reduction 
12.  SEDP 2006–2010 recognizes that social protection and targeted programs for poverty 
reduction are required for inclusive growth. Social protection expands opportunities, enhances 
equity,  and  protects  against  risks  and  shocks.  Targeted  programs  focus  on  particularly 
disadvantaged groups and geographic areas. 
 
13.  Viet Nam fares reasonably well in comparison with the 30 other countries in Asia and the 
Pacific, according to ADB’s social protection index (SPI).3 The SPI values range from a low of 
0.01 (Papua New Guinea) to a high of 0.96 (Japan). Viet Nam’s SPI of 0.38 ranks the country 
13 of 31, just below Nauru but above Malaysia. The SPI is a composite index based on four 
social protection summary indicators. Expenditure measures total expenditure on all social

Strategy Paper─Annual Progress Report─Joint Staff Advisory Note. Washington, DC. 
http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2006/cr0671.pdf

Appendix 2  37  
protection programs as a share of gross domestic product (0.041 in Viet Nam). Coverage 
measures the beneficiaries of targeted social protection as a share of the reference population 
group, i.e., the elderly, the disabled, the unemployed, etc. (0.40). Distribution calculates the 
number of beneficiaries who are poor as a share of the poor population, or efficiency of poverty 
targeting (0.71). Impact is the average social protection expenditure for each poor person as a 
share of the national poverty line (0.17). Viet Nam falls into the group of countries with an 
average SPI ranking (the average for Asia is 0.36). The policy priority for countries with average 
SPIs is likely to be improving the efficiency, functioning, and targeting of current programs. The 
social protection summary indicator for impact, at 17%, is lower than the average of 23% for 
Asia. 
 
14.  Social  Safety  Nets.  Social  safety  net  programs  (e.g.,  social  assistance  and  child 
protection) account for about 30% of Viet Nam’s total social protection expenditure. The target 
group coverage ratios are 65% of the poor, 100% of the disabled, and 62% of targeted children. 
Viet Nam’s overall social protection summary indicator for coverage, at 0.40, is high; only eight 
other countries have values higher. In a decentralized country like Viet Nam, the amount of 
budgetary resources at the local level has a major influence on the ability to implement social 
policy, deliver social services, and provide safety nets. According to the Vietnam Development 
Report 2008, powerful allocation norms have been set up to transfer resources from richer to 
poorer provinces (on a scale much larger than similar efforts in richer countries). However, there 
has been less progress in the allocation of provincial resources to districts, communes, and 
below. In general, the quality of programs targeted at specific households is mixed. Some have 
considerable impact, but others are less effective. 
 
15.  Labor  Market  Programs.  The  SPI  assessment  of social  protection  expenditure  by 
category of program shows that only 7.7% of the total goes toward labor market programs 
(direct  employment  generation,  labor  exchanges  and  other  employment  services,  skills 
development and training, and the development of labor legislation). 
 
16.  Each of the country’s 63 provinces has a vocational training center under the local 
department  of  labor,  invalids,  and  social  affairs.  The  Government  implements  a  National 
Targeted Program on Job Generation and provides credit through the National Fund for Job 
Creation and the Social Policy Bank. The vocational training system is being strengthened and 
diversified  to  meet  the  demands  of  the  labor  market.  The  Government  does  not  provide 
unemployment insurance, but it does give (i) allowances for early retirement, (ii) access to credit 
for opening new business after retirement, and (iii) free vocational training for the poor in 
government-run vocational training centers. In the ADB SPI analysis of target group coverage 
ratios, only 9.4% of the unemployed and underemployed are covered by social protection 
programs. 
 
17.  Viet Nam introduced a minimum wage for foreign-invested companies in 1990 and for 
domestic enterprises in 1993. The former varies by region; the latter is uniform throughout the 
country. The ratio between minimum and average wages in domestic enterprises has increased 
moderately,  from  25%  in  1998  to  32%  in  2006,  but  minimum  wages  applying  to  foreign 
companies remain substantially higher. The margin varies from more than 50% to more than 
90% depending on the region. This is incompatible with the national treatment principle of the 
World Trade Organization. Thus, Viet Nam needs to unify the minimum wage, which will mean 
increasing the domestic enterprise minimum wage. This may affect employment creation and 
formalization.

38  Appendix 2   
18.  Old-Age Pensions. Until 1993, Viet Nam only had an old-age pension program for civil 
servants  and  workers  in  state-owned  enterprises. The  coverage  was extended  in  1993  to 
domestic and foreign private enterprises on a contributory basis. Viet Nam Social Security 
administers these programs. There is also a noncontributory scheme (administered by MOLISA) 
for people over 85 who lack resources. The system is now undergoing major and rapid reform. 
The first Social Insurance Law was passed in 2006, with various elements being implemented 
over 2007–2009. The aim is to expand coverage and ensure financial sustainability. Along with 
a voluntary pension program for informal sector workers, the compulsory program applies to all 
Vietnamese working in any enterprise provided they have at least a 3-month contract. To 
receive a pension, participants must contribute for 20 years. The minimum pension is set equal 
to the minimum wage; the maximum is 75% of the average salary. Retirement age is low at 55 
for women and 60 for men. The main difference between the voluntary and the compulsory 
programs is that the voluntary scheme does not have a ceiling on contributions and or a 
minimum pension. 
 
19.  Participation in the compulsory scheme is growing steadily from its low base, with about 
8  million  active  contributors  in  2007  (18%  of  the  labor  force  and  54%  of  employment  in 
state-owned enterprises, foreign companies, and private domestic firms). In 2007, there were 
about 1.9 million pensioners, about 25% of the population 60 years old and above. However, 
almost half of pension spending went to the richest two quintiles, with only 2% to the poorest. 
Thus, the pension system is not pro-poor. Whether the national voluntary pension program for 
the informal sector will attract many members is not yet clear. The largest voluntary pension 
scheme in Viet Nam operates in the province of Nghe An, with about 85,000 participants in 
2007. 
 
20.  Targeted Programs for Poverty Reduction.4 Viet Nam implements a host of targeted 
programs to reach the most disadvantaged. Some provide cash support to particular vulnerable 
groups; others deliver other forms of targeted assistance to disadvantaged groups or regions. 
The pricing of utilities such as water can also be based on different groups’ ability to pay. Cash 
transfers  are  paid  out  by  social  guarantee  funds,  which  provide  regular  relief  to  defined 
vulnerable groups and to war veterans and war invalids. Subsidies are provided through the 
National Targeted Program for Poverty Reduction (NTPPR) 2006–2010, formerly the Hunger 
Eradication and Poverty Reduction Program. Development assistance to poor communes is 
managed through Program 135 (program for socioeconomic development in communes facing 
extreme hardship in ethnic minority and mountainous areas); Program 132 and Program 134, 
which seek to provide ethnic minorities with agricultural and residential land, housing, and water 
supply; and the Support Program for Fast and Sustainable Poverty Reduction in 61 Poor 
Districts. These initiatives differ in the nature of the benefits they provide, as well as in the 
targeting techniques they apply to identify beneficiaries. 
 
21.  The NTPPR targets households that have been identified as poor using the MOLISA 
methodology.  Activities  under  NTPPR  fall  into  three  areas:  (i)  development  of  productive 
activities of the poor, (ii) provision of access to basic services, and (iii) capacity development 
and  monitoring.  The  first  area  includes  the  largest  single  component  of  the  NTPPR,  the 
provision of preferential credit. The second area focuses on health care, education, housing, 
water supply, and legal aid. A total of D43.5 trillion has been allocated to this program over a 5 
years, with 60% going to the provision of preferential credit. The central budget covers 29% of

Appendix 2  39  
the envelope, with local governments and local communities expected to contribute a further 5% 
and 6%, respectively.  
 
22.  Program 135 is geographically targeted. The first phase of the program allocated D700 
million per year to identified communes. Poverty maps show that the communes targeted by the 
program were generally those with higher poverty rates. Targeting issues arise at lower levels, 
as resource allocation may favor wealthier villages within a commune, and not everyone in a 
village is necessarily poor. The second phase of Program 135 (to be implemented during 2006–
2010) is tackling these issues by requiring the inclusion of both poorer villages within the 
poorest “zone III” communes and the poorest villages in the less-poor “zone II” communes. 
 
23.  The Support Program for Fast and Sustainable Poverty Reduction in 61 Poor Districts 
was  approved  in  December  2008.  It  targets  61  districts  where  the  poverty  rate  based  on 
MOLISA's methodology was more than 50% in 2006. The program aims to reduce the poverty 
rate in the target districts to less than 40% by 2010, to the corresponding provincial average 
poverty rate by 2015, and to the corresponding regional average poverty rate by 2020. The 
activities  under  the  program  include  providing  free  rice  to  poor  households;  supporting 
agriculture, forestry, fishery, and food processing businesses (especially those being set up or 
run by poor households); improving the quality of and access to vocational training; developing 
transport and irrigation infrastructure; and providing incentives to businesses for investing and 
creating jobs in the target districts. The total cost of the program for 2009–2020 is estimated at 
D160 trillion, of which D10.5 trillion was transferred from the central to local budgets in early 
2009.

60  Appendix 9 
SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
Country/Project Title: Viet Nam/Support for the Implementation of the Poverty Reduction Program V—Subprogram 2 
 
Lending/Financing  Department/  Southeast Asia Department/ 
Policy-Based   
Modality:  Division:  Viet Nam Resident Mission 
       
I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.   Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
 
Viet Nam’s poverty reduction strategy is embedded in the Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010. SEDP 
2006–2010 provides for a broad range of policy reforms and a large number of investment projects aimed at reducing poverty. 
One of its targets is to reduce the poverty rate (based on the methodology of the Ministry of Labor, Invalids, and Social 
Affairs) from 20.2% in 2005 to 10%–11% in 2010. SEDP 2006–2010 also aspires to strengthen the foundations for 
environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive economic growth and a continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. The 
joint International Development Association–International Monetary Fund staff advisory note of 5 December 2006 on Viet 
Nam’s poverty reduction strategy concluded that SEDP 2006–2010 has the key features of a poverty reduction strategy and is 
likely to lead to economic growth and poverty reduction.a 
 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program (2007–2010) for Viet Nam is aligned with SEDP 2006–
2010. It provides for assistance to the Government in both carrying out the policy reforms and implementing the investment 
projects that are needed for the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010. Its primary focus is on promoting business-
led, pro-poor economic growth by developing infrastructure, improving the business environment, strengthening financial and 
related market institutions, and building up human capital. The country strategy and program also aims to foster social 
inclusiveness, enhance management of the environment, and improve governance.b 
 
In 2008, ADB approved the Support for the Implementation of the Poverty Reduction Program (SIPRP) V, a program cluster 
with three chronologically ordered subprograms, and a loan for its subprogram 1.c  SIPRP V is intended to help—through the 
poverty reduction support credit (PRSC) process led by the World Bank—the Government carry out policy reforms needed for 
the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010. Subprogram 1 of SIPRP V provided parallel financing with the World 
Bank's PRSC 7, and subprogram 2 will provide parallel financing with PRSC 8 within the framework of the PRSC process.  
 
The policy reforms supported by SIPRP V and, in particular by its subprogram 2, closely match the priorities of ADB's country 
strategy and program (2007–2010) for Viet Nam. They fall into the following four broad reform areas: 
 
(i)  Business development. Improving financial management and corporate governance of state-owned enterprises 
(SOEs), developing the financial and private sectors, and improving the quality of infrastructure services. 
(ii)  Social inclusion. Improving the quality of health care and education and access to these services.  
(iii)  Natural resource management. Strengthening the management of water resources and the protection of the 
environment. 
(iv)  Governance. Improving planning processes, strengthening public financial management and pubic administration, 
and reducing corruption. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
Although Viet Nam made remarkable progress in poverty reduction in the past 15–20 years, much remains to be done. The 
absolute number of people living in poverty is still large. The incidence of poverty varies significantly across regions and is 
relatively high in the rural areas and among ethnic minorities. Since the number of near-poor people is large, the vulnerability 
of the population to poverty is high. A high inflation rate and, in particular, the steep rise in food prices pushed many low-
income households, especially in urban areas, into poverty in 2008. As economic activity slowed sharply, unemployment 
increased and more households, particularly in rural areas, fell into poverty in the first several months of 2009.  
 
2.  Design Features  
 
Subprogram 2 of SIPRP V will help Viet Nam resolve the remaining issues in poverty reduction by helping the Government 
carry out a broad range of policy reforms needed for the successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010. These reforms will 
improve governance, develop businesses, and stimulate economic growth. Business development and economic growth will 
create news jobs, raise incomes, and make more resources available for social protection. Poor regions, ethnic minorities,

Appendix 9  61 
and poor and near-poor people in rural and urban areas are likely to benefit from new jobs, higher incomes, and increased 
availability of resources for social protection. The reforms supported by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V will also make growth more 
socially inclusive by improving the quality of health care and education as well as access to these services. 
 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending 
The main positive impact on poverty of the policy reforms supported by subprogram 2 of SIPRP V will be indirect. These 
reforms will help reduce poverty in Viet Nam primarily by improving the allocation of scarce resources and fostering socially 
inclusive economic growth.  
 
Some of the policy actions under the subprogram will also make a direct contribution to poverty reduction. In particular, action 
1.4 (adopt a pricing system for electricity from renewable energy and provide incentives for government procurement of 
energy-efficient equipment) will help reduce poverty in areas with untapped renewable energy resources and high incidence 
of poverty (e.g., mountainous areas inhabited by ethnic minorities) by making the production of electricity from renewable 
energy commercially more attractive. Action 2.1 (formulate an education development strategy for the period up to 2020 
focusing on the equity of learning outcomes and the relevance of contents) will help improve access of the poor, ethnic 
minorities, and other disadvantaged groups of the population to education and ensure that there are no significant differences 
in learning outcomes among children of different backgrounds (i.e., children from poor households do as well as children from 
rich households, children from remote areas do as well as children from other areas, and ethnic minority children do as well 
as ethnic majority children). Action 3.1 (issue regulations aimed to ensure financial sustainability of irrigation services and 
provide financial relief for poor farmers) will make irrigation services more affordable for poor farmers. Millions of Vietnamese 
people (including the poor) who are expected to be adversely affected by the climate change will benefit from action 3.2 
(approve  a  national  target  program  for  adapting  to  climate  change  and  allocate  institutional  responsibilities  for  its 
implementation). Action 4.1 (conduct a midterm review of SEDP 2006–2010 and strengthen the result-based approach in the 
monitoring and evaluation framework for planning) will help make future SEDPs more effective in reducing poverty. 
 
The policy reforms supported by subprogram 2 of SIPRP will help Viet Nam make further progress on the targets of the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDG) concerning extreme poverty, hunger, and the incidence of malaria and other diseases, 
which Viet Nam has already achieved. The reforms will also help Viet Nam attain the MDG targets pertaining to primary 
school completion, gender equality in education, and environmental sustainability. 
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
 
While the policy actions under subprogram 2 of SIPRP V are likely to affect all population groups in Viet Nam, they are likely 
to have a relatively larger impact on the poor, ethnic minorities, rural population, and people who can be adversely affected by 
climate  change.  The  reason  is  that  the  actions  are  aimed  at  reducing  poverty  by  fostering  socially  inclusive  and 
environmentally sustainable economic growth, and the incidence of poverty is high among ethnic minorities and in the rural 
areas.    
 
The poverty rate based on the methodology of the Ministry of Labor, Invalids, and Social Affairs suggests that 11.3 million 
people lived below the official poverty line in 2008. According to the household survey data, 13.5 million people lived in 
poverty and 5.7 million people suffered from hunger in 2006. Rural areas accounted for 73.3% of the total population but 
93.6% of the poor. Ethnic minorities made up 13.5% of the total population but 44.4% of the poor.d 
 
Climate change is expected to affect millions of people in Viet Nam. According to one study, a sea level rise of 1 meter would 
affect 11% of Viet Nam's population. The proportion of people adversely affected by the sea level rise would be particularly 
high in the Mekong River and Sun Red River deltas.e 
 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Provide a summary of consultations and participation during the project preparation. 
 
The Viet Nam Development Report 2007 provides analytical underpinnings for SIPRP V and, in particular, it subprogram 2. 
The report was jointly prepared by 16 development agencies (including ADB) in 2006. The report analyzes medium-term 
development challenges facing Viet Nam and reviews the Government’s strategy for overcoming these challenges (as set out 
in SEDP 2006–2010). It also proposes a set of policy actions aimed at successful implementation of SEDP 2006–2010. Some 
of these actions were covered by subprogram 1 of SIPRP V. 
 
Subprogram 2 of SIPRP V is to support actions included in the policy matrix for PRSC 8, focusing on those actions that 
complement actions supported by ADB’s other program loans to Viet Nam or are otherwise important to ADB’s operations in

62  Appendix 9 
the country. In late 2008, the development agencies participating in the PRSC process (including ADB) agreed among 
themselves as well as with the Government, civil society, and private sector on the initial policy matrix for PRSC 8. Between 
December 2008 and May 2009, the development agencies and the Government held several rounds of consultations on the 
initial policy matrix for PRSC 8. In May 2009, they agreed on the final policy matrix for PRSC 8. The actions to be covered by 
subprogram 2 of SIPRP were selected—in consultation with the Government and various units within ADB—from the actions 
included in the final policy matrix of PRSC 8. 
 
2.  What level of consultation and participation (C&P) is envisaged during the project implementation and monitoring?  
  Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making       Empowerment

If a C&P plan was prepared, describe key features and resources provided to implement the plan (including budget, 
consultant input, etc.). If no, explain why. 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
1.  Key Issues. 
 
Viet Nam has made good progress in eliminating gender disparities in recent years and is on track to achieve the MDG target 
for gender equality in education. However, some gender disparities remain. Notably, only 10.9% of land use certificates for 
agricultural land and 31.3% of land use certificates for forest land bore the name of both husband and wife in 2006. More boys 
than girls were enrolled in primary and secondary education, whereas more girls than boys were enrolled in vocational and 
university education in the 2006–2007 school year.f While children from poor households have less education and health care 
opportunities than children from rich households, girls from poor households have even less opportunities than boys from 
poor households. Living conditions in mountainous and other remote areas are particularly harsh for girls and women.   
 
Some policy actions under subprogram 2 of SIPRP V will help eliminate remaining gender gaps. For example, action 1.4 
(adopt a pricing system for electricity from renewable energy and provide incentives for government procurement of energy-
efficient equipment) will raise living standards of girls and women in mountainous and other remote areas by stimulating the 
production of electricity from renewable energy in those areas and improving girls and women's access to modern education 
and health facilities and equipment (such as computers and the internet). Action 2.1 (formulate an education development 
strategy for the period up to 2020 focusing on the equity of learning outcomes and the relevance of contents) will help 
eliminate the remaining disparities in education. Farm households headed by women will benefit more from action 3.1 (issue 
regulations to ensure financial sustainability of irrigation services and provide financial relief for poor farmers) than farm 
households headed by men because the incidence of poverty among the former is higher than among the latter. Action 4.1. 
(conduct a midterm review of SEDP 2006–2010 and strengthen the resulted-based approach in the monitoring and evaluation 
framework for planning) helps make future SEDPs more effective in addressing gender issues.
